title: Protocol for host volatile collection and mosquito behavior assays
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Selection and starvation of female mosquitoes
Timing: ∼1 day
This part describes the preparation of female mosquitoes.
Before each assay, sort mosquitoes cultured 7–14 days after eclosion under cold anesthesia at 4°C and release the females into a small nylon cage (20 × 20 × 20 cm).
Fast the female mosquitoes for 16–24 h before exposure to host odor, without access to water and sugar.
Note: All female mosquitoes used in the behavioral assays should be mated previously but should not have consumed a blood meal.
Collection of volatiles from AG6 mice
Timing: ∼2 days
This procedure aims to provide detailed steps for collecting volatiles from AG6 mice (or other animals).
Use six- to eight-week-old female mice for the animal studies.8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8],9[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9] Inject the female AG6 mice intraperitoneally with 2 × 103 p.f.u. of either the DENV2 43 strain or the ZIKV PRVABC59 strain.
Use the collection device to collect volatiles released from AG6 mice (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2264-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Schematic representation of a volatile collection device

In step 1, connect the Teflon tubes to an activated charcoal filter and a Super Q adsorption filter, and the length of the Teflon tubes is determined according to the actual conditions. In step 2, connect the Teflon tubes prepared in step 1 to the glass chamber (20 cm in height and 10 cm in bottom diameter) and the air sampling instrument. In step 3, the mice (or other animals) are anesthetized and placed into the glass chamber, and the glass chambers are tightly sealed with metal caps. In step 4, air purified through an activated charcoal filter and then pump through the chamber at a flow rate of 1 L/min by air sampling instruments. Volatiles released from mice (or other animals) are absorbed by the Super Q 80/100 mesh.
Purify the air through an activated charcoal filter.
Pump the clean air through the chamber at a flow rate of 1 L/min by a vacuum pump.
Collect the volatiles released from healthy or DENV2/ZIKV-infected mice in a glass tube containing 100 mg of Super Q 80/100 mesh (GEEQ-008613, CNW).
Use healthy mice and mice infected with DENV2/ZIKV for 4 and 6 days for volatile collection. Three time periods should be used for volatile collection every day: daytime (lights on, 9:00–11:00 AM, 3:00–5:00 PM) and nighttime (lights off, 7:00–11:00 PM).
Extract the collected volatile compounds by 600 μL of n-hexane (1.00795, Sigma‒Aldrich) and store at −80°C.
Note: To avoid interference of feces and urine with volatile collection, AG6 mice are anesthetized with 0.75% pentobarbital (P3761, Sigma‒Aldrich) in glass chambers.
Note: To avoid environmental effects, cage the healthy and DENV2/ZIKV-infected mice together between experiments.
Collection of volatiles from dengue patients and healthy donors
Timing: Variable

This procedure aims to provide detailed steps for collecting volatiles from dengue patients and healthy donors (or other individuals not eligible for collecting volatiles with the device shown in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
Clinically diagnose the dengue patients from outpatient services with an immune colloidal gold kit against DENV nonstructural protein-1 (NS1) antigen.10[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10] Record the age and gender information of dengue patients and healthy donors.
Use a PDMS Twister with a 1-cm-long/1-mm phase thickness in the human volatile collection steps. Before usage, the Twisters are conditioned at 290°C under a purified helium stream for 2 h.
Install the PDMS Twister prepared in advance on a collection device specifically designed for volatile compound collection.11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11]
Collect the human volatile compounds from armpit skin surfaces of dengue patients and healthy donors. Use a special roller device designed especially for VOC profiling of human skin.11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11] Place a preconditioned Twister in the collection device.
Roll over two separate 5-cm-long stretches (10-cm2 skin area) of armpit skin from each donor with the PDMS Twister for 10 min.
After collection, store the PDMS Twister at −20°C until use.
Use a two-step extraction protocol to elute the human volatile compounds adsorbed on the PDMS Twister (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2264-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. A two-step procedure for volatile elution from the PDMS Twister
In step 1, extract the nonpolar volatiles adsorbed on the PDMS Twister. Stir the PDMS Twister at 700 rpm with 1 mL of n-hexane at room temperature (22°C–26°C) for 60 min. We designate the n-hexane extracts as nonpolar compounds. In step 2, elute the polar volatile compounds. Stir the PDMS Twister at 700 rpm with 1 mL of methanol at room temperature (22°C–26°C) for 60 min, and the methanol extracts are designated as polar compounds.
First, we prepare n-hexane and methanol to extract the volatiles adsorbed on the PDMS Twister.

Stir the PDMS Twister at 700 rpm with 1 mL of n-hexane in sealed 12-mL vials (B7999-12A, Thermo Scientific) at room temperature (22°C–26°C) for 60 min. Designate the n-hexane extracts as the primary extract.
Stir the PDMS Twister at 700 rpm with 1 mL of methanol in sealed 12-mL vials at room temperature (22°C–26°C) for 60 min. Designate the methanol extracts as the secondary extract.
Store the n-hexane extracts and methanol extracts at −80°C.
Critical: To avoid contamination from volatile compounds released by the collectors, gloves should be worn during the collection process.
Collection of volatiles from mouse skin bacteria
Timing: ∼3 days
This procedure provides methods for culturing skin bacteria in LB liquid medium and detailed steps for collecting volatiles from the fermentation supernatant.
Prepare a 250-mL triangular flask containing 100 mL of LB liquid medium.
Culture individual bacterial strains in liquid LB medium for 3 days at 30°C and 180 rpm.
To collect the volatile compounds produced by the bacteria, centrifuge the culture at 13,000 × g for 10 min to discard the cell mass.
After the cell mass is separated by centrifugation, use the fresh fermentation supernatant for the behavioral assays or store at −80°C until use.
Note: To avoid contamination, use all glass products in steps 14–17.
Critical: To avoid light decomposition of volatile compounds in the fresh fermentation supernatant, brown sterile sample bottles should be used for storage. If a brown sample bottle is not available, the outside of the bottle should be wrapped in aluminum foil.
Mosquito behavioral assay in mice
Timing: ∼2 h
In this experiment, we test the mosquito behavioral responses to volatile cues from healthy and DENV2/ZIKV-infected mice. Place the healthy and DENV2/ZIKV-infected mice in the glass chamber, and pump the volatiles into the observing cage by constant airflow.

Inject six- to eight-week-old female mice intraperitoneally with 2 × 103 p.f.u. of either the DENV2 43 strain or the ZIKV PRVABC59 strain.
Used a three-cage olfactometer (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A) to perform a behavioral assay on the mice. Before each assay, release 60 female mosquitoes into the middle cage for at least 30 min to acclimatize them to the environment.
During the assay, place healthy or DENV2/ZIKV-infected mice into a glass chamber (20 cm in height and 10 cm for the bottom diameter), and seal the jar tightly with metal caps (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).
Connect the glass jars containing the healthy or DENV2/ZIKV-infected mice to the left and right chambers in the three-cage olfactometer by Teflon tubes.
Pump the volatiles released from AG6 mice into the three-cage olfactometer.
Purify the air through an activated charcoal filter.
Pump the clean air through the chamber containing the mice at a flow rate of 1 L/min by a vacuum pump.
Pump the volatiles released from the healthy or DENV2/ZIKV-infected mice into the left and right chambers, respectively.
After 30 min, count the number of mosquitoes in each cage.
Note: To avoid interference of feces and urine with the behavioral assay, AG6 mice were anesthetized with 0.75% pentobarbital in glass chambers.
Note: To avoid environmental effects, cage the healthy and DENV2/ZIKV-infected mice together between experiments.
Mosquito behavioral assay for human volatiles
Timing: Variable
In this assay, the volatile extracts from healthy donors and dengue patients are applied to filter papers, and the filter papers are subsequently attached to the palm of a volunteer for the mosquito behavioral assay.

Use a two-port olfactometer (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B) to perform the behavioral assay with the volatiles collected from healthy donors and dengue patients. Before each assay, release 60 female mosquitoes into a large Plexiglas box for at least 30 min to acclimatize to the environment.
Prepare the filter paper (3 cm in diameter).
Apply 100 μL of volatile extracts collected from the skin of healthy donors or dengue patients to the filter paper. Use an equal volume of n-hexane (or methanol) solvent as a control.
Place the filter paper on the left and right palms of one donor.
The donor places his or her left and right arms in the two stimulus ports.
After 30 min, count the number of mosquitoes in each cylindrical trap.
Note: To avoid interference of exogenous volatile compounds released by the donor (from whom the volatiles were extracted) and the volunteer (who provided the hand for the procedure), both the donor and the volunteer are asked to avoid spicy foods, garlic, and alcohol and use unperfumed soap 24 h before the behavioral assay.
Note: The distance between the two arms of the donors and the smaller cylindrical traps is equal.
Mosquito behavioral assay for skin bacteria
Timing: Variable
This experiment explains how to study the mosquito attraction response to skin bacteria. Fresh bacterial fermentation supernatant is applied to the skin of AG6 mice, and the mice treated with fermentation supernatant or LB liquid medium are placed in a glass jar, as shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A.
Prepare the fresh bacterial fermentation supernatant. Alternatively, melt the fermentation supernatant (store at −80°C) at 4°C in the refrigerator.

Use the three-cage olfactometer (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A) to perform the behavioral assay of the bacterial volatiles. Before each assay, release 60 female mosquitoes into the middle cage for at least 30 min to acclimatize to the environment.
Apply one milliliter of the bacterial fermentation supernatant to the back and abdomen (approximately 10 cm2 in total) of healthy AG6 mice using a paintbrush. Use an equal volume of LB liquid medium as a control.
Treat the AG6 mice with bacterial fermentation supernatant or LB liquid medium.
Place the treated mice into the glass chamber. Connect the chamber to the left or right cage of the three-cage olfactometer by Teflon tubes.
Pump the volatiles released from the mice into the three-cage olfactometer.
Purify the air through the activated charcoal filter.
Pump the clean air through the mice treated with bacterial fermentation supernatant or LB liquid medium.
Pump the volatiles released from the mice with bacterial fermentation supernatant or LB liquid medium into the left and right chambers, respectively.
After 30 min, count the number of mosquitoes in each cage.
Note: To avoid the loss of volatile compounds from the bacteria fermentation supernatant, the fermentation supernatant stored at −80°C is melted at 4°C in the refrigerator or on ice. The freezing fermentation supernatant is not placed in a water bath for rapid melting.
Critical: After thawing the fresh fermentation supernatant (stored at −80°C) at 4°C in the refrigerator, the bottle containing the fermentation supernatant is vortexed for 30 s to evenly mix the supernatant.
